title: Ebrahim Hakimi
text:
Ebrahim Hakimi (15 August 1871 – 19 October 1959) was an Iranian statesman, who served as <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Iran">prime minister of Iran</a> on three occasions.
Early life and education.
Born in <a href="Tabriz">Tabriz</a>, Ḥakimi was part of "an old and prominent family of court physicians", who traced their status as far back as the 17th century, "starting with the eponym of the family, Moḥammad-Dāvud Khan Ḥakim" who served at the courts of the <a href="Safavid%20dynasty">Safavid</a> kings ("<a href="shah">shah</a>s") <a href="Safi%20of%20Persia">Safi</a> (1629-1642) and <a href="Abbas%20II%20of%20Persia">Abbas II</a> (1642-1666). This ancestor of Ebrahim was also the founder of the <a href="Hakim%20Mosque%2C%20Isfahan">Hakim Mosque located in Isfahan</a>.
After finishing elementary and high school in Tabriz, Hakimi attended <a href="Dar%20ul-Funun%20%28Persia%29">Dar ol-Fonoon</a> in Tehran, and finished advanced studies in Medicine in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>.
Career.
Hakimi served as royal physician to <a href="Mozzafar-al-Din%20Shah">Mozzafar-al-Din Shah</a>. He then became a member of the Parliament, and served as cabinet minister 17 times, as prime minister for three terms, and as speaker of the <a href="Senate%20of%20Iran">Senate of Iran</a>.
His second tenure as prime minister was short-lived (three months) as the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviets</a>, angry over his refusal to grant them an oil concession in Northern Iran, inspired Azerbaijani <a href="Communism">Communists</a> to declare independence from Iran. Soviet troops occupying the Northern regions refused to allow Iranian troops to enter the region to put down the uprising. Hakimi submitted the issue to the <a href="UN%20Security%20Council">UN Security Council</a> and resigned from office as a protest of Soviet actions in January 1946.
Death.
Hakimi died in <a href="Tehran">Tehran</a> at the age of 88.
